did.head: Summary Information

repository.label: Repository

corpname.normal: Indiana University, Bloomington. Archives of African American Music and Culture

repository.corpname: Indiana University, Archives of African American Music and Culture (AAAMC)

did.abstract: Series G, "Music Industry Interviews," consists of transcripts and audiocassettes of interviews primarily conducted by Portia K. Maultsby between 1981-1986 as part of her research on the Black music industry. The remainder of the series in this collection are still in the process of being accessioned and are unavailable for general research and public use.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Reference copies and transcripts for most, but not all, of the audiocassettes in Series G, "Music Industry Interviews," are available for in-house use at the Archives of African American Music and Culture, Indiana University. Please refer to the information included under each interview for details. If you would like to access an item without a reference copy and/or transcript, please contact our staff well in advance of your visit for details.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Portia K. Maultsby received a Ph.D. degree in Ethnomusicology from the University of Wisconsin--Madison, and is a professor emeritus in the Department of Folklore and Ethnomusicology, the former director of the Archives of African American Music and Culture, and a former adjunct professor of African American and African Diaspora Studies at Indiana University. She teaches historical and theoretical courses on African American music and culture in ethnomusicology. Her research topics have centered on Black religious and popular music and she has lectured and conducted workshops throughout the United States, as well as in England, The Netherlands, Russia, Cuba, Zimbabwe, and Malawi. She is co-editor of African American Music : An Introduction, (Routledge Press, 2006). She also has served as consulting scholar for PBS, BBC, and NPR productions on African American music. In addition to her scholarly work, Professor Maultsby is a keyboard player and the founding director of the IU Soul Revue, a touring ensemble specializing in the performance of African American popular music.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Currently organized into one series and the following subseries:
Subseries 1. Interviews by Maultsby, 1979-1989
Subseries 2. Interviews by Various Interviewers and Miscellaneous Recordings, 1979-1989
Each subseries is arranged alphabetically by interviewee's last name or the title in the case of non-interviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 168 audiocassette recordings of interviews; complete or partial transcripts are available for many. The bulk of the interviews (138 cassettes) were conducted in person by Maultsby between 1981-1986 as part of her research on the Black music industry. The interviews provide an aural documentation of the history and development of rhythm and blues music through the personal narratives of musicians, composers, producers, deejays, and record company executives. In particular, Maultsby's interviews trace the emergence of Black music divisions and the promotion of Black artists by major record labels. Other significant issues emphasized in the discussions are cultural identity, gender, appropriation, aesthetics, and the racially defined politics and marketing practices of the industry. Of equal importance are the stories told by musicians who profoundly shaped the development of rhythm and blues while redefining the direction of American popular music.
All interviews were conducted by Maultsby unless otherwise indicated.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in IUCAT, the IU Libraries' online catalog. Materials about related topics, persons or places can be found by searching the catalog using these terms.

extref.subject: African American sound recording executives and producers

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Donated by Portia K. Maultsby in 2008.

userestrict.head: Usage Restriction
userestrict.p: The collector/donor has granted permission for in-house use only. Researchers may not quote or reproduce any part of this collection without explicit permission from the creator. Other copyrights and intellectual property rights may also apply.

With the exception of Series G, "Music Industry Interviews," the use of this collection is restricted to students enrolled in Maultsby's courses for educational purposes or other parties receiving her explicit permission. Contact AAAMC staff for details.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: SC 18, Portia K. Maultsby Collection, Archives of African American Music and Culture, Indiana University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Preservation and access funded in part by a grant from the GRAMMY® Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Content
scopecontent.p: Lecture by Logan Westbrooks, record executive, on the topic of the music industry; recorded by Portia K. Maultsby at California State University, Los Angeles, California.

Supplementary materials consist of course materials for Westbrooks' PAS 490 course, "Blacks and the Business of Music," taught at UCLA, as well as a course proposal for PAS 469, "The Black Music Industry."

scopecontent.head: Content
scopecontent.p: Reading by Portia K. Maultsby of a printed transcript of an interview with David "Panama" Francis conducted by Milt Hinton for the Jazz Oral History Project, supported by the National Endowment of the Arts, Smithsonian Institution; recording date and location unknown.
Supplementary materials include correspondence between Francis and Maultsby, news clippings, photocopies of articles and promotional materials, and Maultsby's notes on Francis.

note.label: Note
note.p: Transcript is the original transcript for Hinton's interview and not a direct transcript of cass 1261--cass 1263. Cass 1263, side B contains a broadcast of a spotlight interview with David "Panama" Francis, on the program "Jazz at One" on WKCR radio, date and location unknown.
